article.headline: Washington 83, Oregon 74
article.story: SEATTLE (AP) -- Nate Robinson couldn't forget the name-calling in Eugene, so he threw one down to even the score. Robinson scored 20 points, including an uncontested dunk at the buzzer, while Brandon Roy and Bobby Jones added 18 apiece to lead Washington to an 83-74 win over Oregon on Thursday night. The 5-foot-9 Robinson punctuated the win with his late dunk, and the teams scuffled at the scorer's table afterward when they were supposed to shake hands. Robinson said he was getting back at Oregon fans who called him "Gary Coleman" during an 84-74 road loss Jan. 15. "It was all that Gary Coleman, all the negative stuff," Robinson said. "Their crowd called me names. I just took off, took flight." Coaches pushed players toward the locker rooms, and Oregon's Andre Joseph had to be restrained by teammates. "I talked to Nate and told him he's a tremendous player with way too much class to do that," Ducks coach Ernie Kent said. Joseph had an opportunity for a late breakaway dunk when the teams met last month in Eugene, but he turned the ball over on the play. "We had the same opportunity to do something like that at Mac Court but we didn't do it," Oregon's Luke Jackson said. "Everyone who's in that position wants to do that, but it's a matter of class and not doing it." Mike Jensen had 14 points and 10 rebounds for the Huskies (11-9, 6-6 Pac-10), who turned it on midway through the second half. Washington closed with a 31-9 run that left the Ducks (11-7, 6-5) angry and frustrated. Jackson, limited to three minutes in the first half because of early foul trouble, finished with a season-low 11 points. The Ducks, averaging 15.4 turnovers, hurt themselves with a season-high 26. "We played well for 30 minutes," Kent said. "Then we let the game slip away in the last 10 minutes and Washington had a lot to do with that." Joseph led Oregon with 19 points, and Mitch Platt and Ian Crosswhite each scored 15 for the Ducks, who had won four of five against Washington but remained winless in their last three visits to Seattle. The Huskies reached a high mark in their second season under coach Lorenzo Romar. The victory means Washington will have its most Pac-10 wins since the 1999 team finished the conference schedule 10-8. "I continue to repeat this," Romar said. "I'm extremely proud of our guys. We got down several times by double-digit margins but stuck together and were able to come back and win." Roy and Robinson had six points at the break and Jones had five, but they helped the Huskies erase a 36-29 halftime deficit that grew as large as 65-52 with 9:34 to play after dunks by Jackson and Joseph. Washington turned the momentum with a 15-0 burst that included nine consecutive points without allowing Oregon to take a shot. The Huskies are a second-half team, and they steadily slowed the Ducks. Jones scored three baskets and Will Conroy had a 3-point play during an 11-4 burst that tied it at 45 with 15:51 remaining. "It was tough. We fought and fought," Robinson said. "We knew we were going to come back. In the second half, emotions tend to get more fired up. We just had to get more passion for the game." Afterward, much of the talk was about Robinson's late dunk. Robinson said Romar told him not to do it again. "He'll probably make me run, but it was worth it," Robinson said. "I'm not worried about that. I just wanted to give my team a little extra, a little extra dessert. Everybody played together. We kept fighting and fighting."
